qas.question: Who did the Washington Post say Kerry was an envoy for?
When did the Washington Post say Kerry was important envoy?
How, in May 2011, did the WaPo describe Bin Laden's killing?

answers.text: perhaps the most important crossroads yet

qas.question: What did Kerry get from the Pakistanis?

answers.text: the tail-section of the U.S. helicopter which had had to be abandoned at Abbottabad during the bin Laden strike

qas.question: Who was Pakistan's army chief in 2013?

context: Kerry "has emerged in the past few years as an important envoy for <a0_0>Afghanistan and Pakistan<a0_0/> during times of crisis," a Washington Post report stated in <a1_0>May 2011<a1_0/>, as Kerry undertook another trip to the two countries. The killing of Osama bin Laden "has generated <a2_0>perhaps the most important crossroads yet<a2_0/>," the report continued, as the senator spoke at a press conference and prepared to fly from Kabul to Pakistan. Among matters discussed during the May visit to Pakistan, under the general rubric of "recalibrating" the bilateral relationship, Kerry sought and retrieved from the Pakistanis <a3_0>the tail-section of the U.S. helicopter which had had to be abandoned at Abbottabad during the bin Laden strike<a3_0/>. In 2013, Kerry met with Pakistan's army chief <a4_0>Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani<a4_0/> to discuss the peace process with the Taliban in Afghanistan.
